Some Epistemology Matters
3. Some Epistemology Matters

Epistemology has a double fact as its object: the known fact and the
fact of knowing. Knowing is judging an objective (state of affairs,
see below 4.3.1) with entitlement [Berechtigung] – both
external and internal (1915, Chapt. IV). The external entitlement is
provided by the truth or truth-conduciveness of the judged objective,
the internal by evidence [Evidenz]. Evidence is not just a
subjective feeling of conviction; it is an objective feature of the
mental act component of judging (with or without certainty) and not of
its mental content component. (For the difference between the act and
content components of an experience see 4.1 below and the supplement
on
 Presentation of Objects via Psychological Content.)
 Following Brentano, Meinong stands up for a concept of evidence as a
basis for the theory of knowledge. Meinong, for instance, accepts
Brentano’s views on evidence as they pertain to the
“direct–indirect” and “a
priori–a posteriori” distinctions. On the
one hand, direct evidence may be given as a borderline case in inner
perception, in which case it is evidence a posteriori (1906,
§§9–13: 47–68; §26: 111: “The
evidence of inner perception, like that of memory, is mere conjectural
evidence that only reaches the limit of certainty at the present
limit.” [“Die Evidenz der inneren Wahrnehmung ist,
gleich der des Gedächtnisses, bloße Vermutungsevidenz, die
nur an der Gegenwärtigkeitsgrenze die Gewißheitsgrenze
erreicht.”]). On the other hand, it may be given as
knowledge of axiomatic truths, which is evidence a priori
(1906, §1; 1915, §55).

Like Brentano, Meinong also thinks that perceiving and remembering are
always cases of judging and not just representing (1915: 606–7,
613) and that a judgement is indirectly evident if it is concluded
from directly evident judgements. On the other hand, Meinong deviates
in certain respects from Brentano’s theory of evidence. Already
in 1886, Meinong adds “evidence for presumption”
[Vermutungsevidenz] to “evidence for certainty”.
He realizes that we trust in memory, outer perception, and induction
not “blindly and thoughtlessly” or by chance, although our
trust in these abilities does not derive from anything else. It has an
internal justification, which is directly given and neither derived
from the a posteriori evidence of inner perception nor from the a
priori evidence of axioms. In delivering a kind of inference to the
best explanation, Meinong concludes that this confidence can be
counted as a further source of knowledge. It manifests itself as
direct evidence, but evidence for something that may be erroneous, not
certain, and he therefore calls it “direct conjectural
evidence” ([unmittelbare Vermutungsevidenz],
1886: 30–34). Brentano, who only accepted “evidence for
certainty”, strongly disapproved of Meinong’s conception.
He considered Meinong’s introduction of a new special mode of
cognition to be a cutting rather than an unravelling of the Gordian
knot (Kindinger 1965, 22–3). – Actually this disagreement
was the beginning of the estrangement between them.

As Meinong takes objectives as ideal objects, he gives up
Brentano’s definition of truth by means of evidence. Brentano
rejects the correspondence theory of truth, on the grounds that (among
other things) he does not see anything in reality that would
correspond to true negative judgements such as “there are no
unicorns” and defines truth of judgements by their evidence
(Brentano 1930: 139 [82]); see entries on Brentano
and Brentano’s Theory of Judgement). Meinong adopts a
kind of identity theory of truth, which can be seen as a borderline
case of a correspondence theory (Meinong 1915, §7; 1910,
§13; see below 5.6). According to Meinong, the true negative
judgement “there are no unicorns” has a subsistent
objective as its corresponding object (the fact of the non-being of
unicorns). If the objective in question does not subsist (has
non-being) the judgement is false. However, though Meinong does not
use the notion of evidence for a definition of truth, he holds it
still relevant for a truth criterion because truth is a
“proprium” of evidence (1915: 463), and evidence for
certainty (and for presumption, respectively) makes truth (and
probability, respectively) accessible to us. (A classical criticism of
Meinong’s theory of evidence is Nelson 1908: 479–485.)

Meinong’s epistemology turned out to be relevant to analytic
theory of knowledge. Some of Chisholm’s (1966: 38–55)
rules of evidence, for example, are a kind of application of
Meinong’s conception of direct evidence for conjecture. Further,
Meinong’s treatment of epistemic concepts like truth or
entitlement as value concepts anticipates the epistemic
normativity of some internalist positions. It is also worth
mentioning, that Meinong (1915, §54) linked the “principle
of the self-validity of all knowing” [Prinzip der
Selbstgültigkeit alles Erkennens], a kind of prima facie
justification principle, with the fallibilistic
methodological-epistemological “principle of the critical
openness of all knowing” [Prinzip der kritischen
Unabgeschlossenheit alles Erkennens], which says that critical
examination is always possible, since there is always an unverified
judgement left at the end of a justification process.

In his Erfahrungsgrundlagen (1906) Meinong shows that a
perception taken only from a causal point of view cannot explain, for
example, why a perception picks out the distant object and not
something between the perceived object and the observer. In
investigating important features of perception, Meinong (1906,
§22) introduces the concept of a perceptive forum
[Wahrnehmungsforum]. The perceptive forums include the
internal and external moments that affect the content of a perception.
As such the sensing organs, the determinations of the perceived object
and other media come into consideration. The forums are transparent in
the sense that you cannot tell from the perceptive act which forums
are involved. When you see, for example, a piece of chalk, by means of
your spectacles, you see the chalk but you do not notice your eyes and
your spectacles. But it is possible that the role of such media can be
reconstructed by using causal approaches. Fritz Heider already
discussed some of this accounts in his dissertation thesis Zur
Subjektivitaet der Sinnesqualitaeten [On the subjectivity of
sense qualities] (1920), and later, in his paper “Ding und
Medium” [“Thing and Medium”] (1926/27), he took over
Meinong’s conception that media are so to say glass –
glass can mediate the seen of objects, but glass can also be seen as
an object. From this point of view he elaborated fundamental features
of media. Through its interesting, detailed descriptions this study
together with later papers became a forerunner of some modern theories
of media and communication (see, for example, Luhmann 1995;
Krämer 2008).
